Hi All,

I am one of the guys meeting every two weeks with Derek and Philip.

At present, I have read the papers Derek has sent me on NEAT.  And I 
have read the ai_junky book AI Techniques...  I have not done any 
experimentation with NEAT itself.  I have read several other books, 
but have not formally studied any of this at any institution.

My interests at present lie almost exclusively in the domain of 
applying GAs/ANNs to "open perfect information non-random two player 
turned based" games.  Examples would be Checkers (including 
Chinese), Chess (including Chinese), Go, Pente, Reversi, Connect 4, 
etc.

Ultimately, my current "stake in the ground" is Go.  While I have 
not played in some years, I am an 6k Go player.  I have studied many 
games of Go and have a pretty good understanding of what makes Go so 
difficult to "program".  At present, I personally have been able to 
best all of the computer Go programs as recently as 2 years ago.  I 
want to produce a Go playing program that can at least play at the 1 
Dan - Amateur level (6 levels above me).  No one has come even the 
slightest bit close to that goal (all claims to the contrary), even 
in "ideal" circumstances.  And there has been over two decades worth 
of effort.

At present, I am reproducing all of the work from the book Blondie24 
by Fogel (I am the person who recommended Derek read it as he 
mentioned in his introduction).  It is my goal to isolate and 
identify what the influence was for each of the architectual 
decisions made by Fogel in an attempt to get an "intuitive" 
understanding of what kinds of things influenced the "learning 
curve", so to speak, he describes in his text.

In attempting to duplicate Fogel's work, I have implemented a number 
of infrastructure components in Java (currently 1.3.1).  The first 
was all the code necessary for FeedForward/Backprop ANNs of n 
layers.  I have also written a generic/abstract two 
player/board/game implementation stucture with a checkers 
implementation.  I then implemented a full dynamic ply management 
system.  I am currently debugging that.  I also implemented my 
own "distributed computing" system via RMI.  It is not as robust as 
I would like.  Derek has been checking into alternatives, but none 
seem to be "better" yet.

I have written everything in Java and intend on Open Sourcing the 
lot of it, but not until I have at least gone through it once to 
make the code "presentable" (no JavaDocs at this point...only Sun 
syntactically consistent coding conventions).  I personally want to 
spend very little additional time on "infrastructure" development 
and get to experimental development and data generation for 
statistical analysis.

While I think NEAT is going to be a great component to use in 
solving my particular focus on the Go problem, I expect that it will 
be quite some time before I will find it to be genuinely useful on 
the Go problem.  The way I see it, the computational power needed to 
evolve weights into desirable positions is barely within my 
budgetary range at the moment (10-20 PII400s).  The idea of evolving 
weights and topologies is going to require several orders of 
magnitude more processing power (and probably quite a bit more) to 
achieve the goal without some sort of breakthrough in design 
approach (unless there are huge quantities of computational power 
and decades worth of time, neither of which I consider options at 
present).

So, I will mostly be listening to the conversation and asking 
probing and/or leading questions for the most part while I continue 
to focus on completing my "analysis" of the Fogel experiments.


And Derek, thank you for starting this forum.  I appreciate your 
taking that on and managing it.  I love the YahooGroups "event" 
style of sending me an E-mail.  It is much easier to keep up than it 
is to have to "poll" some site every now and again.  I tend to 
forget to poll, get too far behind and eventually stop using the 
site.
